subtitle.en: How toxic are you in relationships?

description.en:
Toxic behavior patterns are repetitive ways of interacting that harm relationships: passive aggression, silent treatment, dramatization, devaluation, victim mentality, and manipulation. Important: we all sometimes display toxicity. This doesn't make you a 'bad person' ‚Äî these are just learned patterns, often from childhood or past experiences. The problem arises when these patterns become the primary way of interacting.

Toxic behavior destroys trust, creates emotional distance, and turns relationships into a source of stress instead of support. But the good news: these patterns can be recognized and changed through awareness and self-work. The first step to change is honestly acknowledging their presence.

This test measures six key toxic patterns. The goal is not to shame you, but to provide a mirror for self-reflection and concrete steps for growth. Remember: problem awareness is already half the solution. If you took this test, it means you're ready for an honest look at yourself, and that takes courage.

target_audience.en: Adults 18+, ready for honest self-reflection and personal growth

important_note.en: üíö IMPORTANT: We all sometimes display toxicity. This test is not to judge you, but to help you grow. Toxic patterns can be changed!

description.en: Expressing anger and dissatisfaction indirectly: sarcasm, sabotage, 'forgetfulness', ambiguous comments
Ignoring, refusing communication, 'cold war' as way to punish or manipulate

Distorting reality, guilt-tripping, emotional blackmail, shifting blame

reverse_scoring.note: No reverse items in this test (all measure toxic patterns)

important_preface.en: üíö First of all: seeing your toxicity is an act of courage, not a reason for shame. Toxic patterns are learned behavior that can be changed. Below is not a verdict, but a map for growth.

description.en: You usually express dissatisfaction directly. That's great! Keep it up.
Sometimes you express anger indirectly. This is natural, but it's important to work on direct communication.

en: When angry, pause and ask yourself: 'What am I really feeling?'
Practice phrase: 'I'm upset by [specific action] because...'
Replace sarcasm with honesty: 'I'm angry' instead of 'Everything's fine'
Remember: direct communication saves time and nerves
Give yourself permission to be openly angry ‚Äî it's normal

description.en: Passive aggression is your main way of expressing dissatisfaction. This destroys trust and creates confusion.

why_it_happens.en: Usually passive aggression appears when direct anger wasn't allowed in childhood or you were punished for expressing emotions directly.

en: IMPORTANT: work with therapist on anger expression
Keep journal: when angry, what do you do instead of direct talk?
Practice 'I-statements': 'I feel...', 'I need...'
Give yourself permission: being angry is normal
Read: 'Living with the Passive-Aggressive Man' (Scott Wetzler)

description.en: You don't use silence as weapon. This is sign of healthy communication.
Sometimes you go silent after conflicts. This is understandable, but it's important to return to conversation.

en: Replace: 'I won't talk to you' ‚Üí 'I need 30 minutes to calm down'
Set timeframe: 'Let's talk in an hour'
Explain to partner: 'I'm not ignoring, I'm processing emotions'
Remember: silence as punishment is manipulation
Always return to conversation, don't leave person hanging

description.en: Silence is your main weapon in conflicts. This is one of the most toxic forms of emotional abuse.

why_it_happens.en: Silent treatment often comes from childhood where ignoring was control method, or from fear of conflicts.

en: CRITICAL: this is emotional abuse, need therapy
Understand: silence causes more pain than words
Practice: 'I'm angry but willing to talk in [time]'
Study healthy conflict processing methods
If can't talk ‚Äî write a message
Read: 'The Emotionally Abusive Relationship' (Beverly Engel)

description.en: You react to problems proportionally to their seriousness. This is mature approach.
Sometimes you exaggerate problems. This may be way to get attention.

en: Before emotional reaction ask yourself: 'Is this really catastrophe?'
Scale 1 to 10: how serious is this objectively?
Replace: 'This is terrible!' ‚Üí 'This is unpleasant but we'll manage'
Find other ways to get attention (direct request)
Remember: drama exhausts both you and partner

description.en: You create drama from everything. This emotionally exhausts others and devalues real problems.

why_it_happens.en: Dramatization often means you were noticed in childhood only through crises, or you fear being ignored.

en: IMPORTANT: work with therapist on emotion regulation
Study techniques: mindfulness, grounding, breathing practices
Keep journal: what triggers dramatic reactions?
Work on direct expression of need for attention
Practice phrase: 'I need your attention' instead of creating drama
Read: 'Emotional Intelligence' (Daniel Goleman)

description.en: You're not inclined toward manipulation and gaslighting. This is sign of ethical communication.
Sometimes you manipulate, possibly without realizing it. Important to learn direct requests.

en: Replace manipulation with direct request: 'I need...' instead of guilt trip
Stop yourself at phrases 'if you love me...'
Acknowledge your words and actions: don't deny obvious
Take responsibility instead of shifting blame
Remember: manipulation = distrust of partner

description.en: You systematically manipulate and distort reality. This is form of emotional abuse (gaslighting).

why_it_happens.en: Manipulation often comes from deep insecurity, fear of rejection, or family behavior patterns.

en: CRITICAL: gaslighting is abuse. Therapy necessary
Acknowledge: your actions cause psychological harm
Study what gaslighting is and why it's unacceptable
Work on self-esteem: manipulation comes from fear
Learn to trust instead of control
Read: 'The Gaslight Effect' (Robin Stern), 'Emotional Abuse'

description.en: Your patterns are mostly healthy. You communicate directly, take responsibility, and don't manipulate. Keep it up!
Sometimes you display toxic patterns, but it's not dominant style. You have awareness for change.

focus_areas.en: Look at specific scales above and work on those scoring above 50%.

description.en: Toxic patterns are frequent part of your communication. This harms relationships, but good you're aware. Time to change.

en: Start with highest score ‚Äî this is your priority
Work with therapist on these patterns
Read recommended literature
Practice alternative communication methods
Be patient with yourself ‚Äî change takes time

description.en: Toxicity is your main communication style. This seriously harms relationships and may be form of emotional abuse. Professional help necessary.

en: CRITICAL: see psychologist IMMEDIATELY
Acknowledge: your behavior causes pain to others
Take timeout from relationships for self-work
Study literature on toxic relationships
Be ready for long change process
If partner leaves ‚Äî these are consequences of your actions

description.en: Your communication style is extremely toxic and constitutes emotional abuse. This destroys partners' psyche. Intensive therapy required.

critical_message.en: ‚ö†Ô∏è THIS IS SERIOUS: Your behavior is abuse. If you don't change, you'll lose people and cause them psychological harm. See specialist in abusive behavior. This is not verdict ‚Äî this is call to action.

steps.title: Acknowledgment
steps.description: You've already taken first step ‚Äî acknowledged problem. This takes courage.

steps.title: Understanding Roots
steps.description: Toxic patterns don't appear from nowhere. Study where they come from: childhood, past relationships, traumas.

steps.title: Working with Therapist
steps.description: Changing deep patterns alone is very difficult. Therapy will accelerate process significantly.

steps.title: Practicing New Skills
steps.description: Learn direct communication, emotional regulation, empathy. These are skills, not innate qualities.

steps.title: Patience with Yourself
steps.description: Change takes time. Relapses are normal. Main thing ‚Äî continue working.

books: Why Do I Do That? (Joseph Burgo) ‚Äî about patterns

reliability.note: Lower test-retest expected as patterns can change with therapy

implementation_notes.retake_recommendation: Every 3-6 months to track progress in changing patterns

support_message.en: Remember: taking this test is already step toward growth. Toxicity is not verdict, but something changeable. üíö
